article.headline: Are you facing early retirement? Hereâs how to prepare
article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NextAvenue.org. The coronavirus pandemic is causing many older workers whoâve lost jobs or been offered early retirement severance packages to decide to pack it in. But takingÂ early retirementÂ can throw a monkey wrench into your future financial security. Thatâs why itâs vital to be cautious before doing it. Iâve talked to several sharp financial advisers for their tips on how best to prepare to retire earlier than you planned; youâll see their suggestions below. 80% of older Americans can't afford to retire - COVID-19 isn't helping âThe numbers suggest that while many older workers displaced by COVID-19 job loss are still seeking work, a large number have dropped out of the labor market entirely,â Jennifer Schramm, a senior strategic policy adviser at the AARP Public Policy Institute wrote in her blog: âDevastating Job Losses May Be Pushing Older Workers Into Retirement.â As a result, Schramm said, âjob losses associated with the pandemic may be leading to a substantial rise in earlier-than-planned retirement.â Frankly, as someone who writes about work and money for people over 50, Iâm worried thatÂ frustration with the job searchÂ or eagerness to grab early-out offers are triggering people to retire early, with potential financial reverberations for the rest of their lives.The risk of claiming Social Security early Take Social Security â or rather, maybe donât. Due to the heightened unemployment of the 2007-09 recession, âthe take-up of Social Security at age 62 jumped from 42.2% in 2007 to 46.9% in 2009,â Alicia H. Munnell, director of the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College, wrote on MarketWatch. And, she added, âI would expect this pattern to repeat itself in the wake of COVID-19.â Hereâs why thatâs a concern: Starting toÂ claim Social Security at 62Â because you arenât working will then lock you into a level of much smaller benefits than if youâd waited until later.Â âBenefits claimed at 70 are 77% higher than those claimed at 62,â Munnell wrote. âIf you qualify for the maximum amount of Social Security and take your benefits at the youngest allowed age, you will receive $2,252 each month,â says Michelle Connell, a Chartered Financial Analyst and owner of Portia Capital Management in Dallas. âIf you wait until you are 70, you will receive $3,980 a month.âThose enticing early retirement offers Undoubtedly, it can be enticing when your employer dangles an early-retirement package compelling enough to grab it and not look back. A growing number of companies from airlines to media firms have been making these offers due to the pandemic. According to CNBC, nearly 4,000 Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.89% Â workers and 2,235 Delta DAL, +0.39% Â pilots signed up for buyouts. Delta offered partial pay for up to three years plus extended health insurance coverage. A spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association told CNBC: âThe voluntary early-out program participation exceeded our expectations.â Such offers might not come around again anytime soon and there is no guarantee your job will be safe. Donât expect your company to follow it with another severance package for future rounds of layoffs, notes Connell. Itâs logical to me that older workers, especially those in spitting distance of age 65, would decide to bid employment adieu. Medicare kicks in at 65 andÂ fullÂ Social Security benefit eligibility starts at 66 or 67. See: Take Social Security at 62? Hereâs when it makes sense to do it Whatever the impetus, the decision to retire is often emotional and fraught with myriad calculations. Itâs generally not a solo decision if you have a spouse or partner or minor children.Money advice for the early retirement decision Hereâs how to help shape a financial framework if youâre contemplating early retirement: Prepare a budget. Retiring early âcan be a difficult decision, since there are so many unknowns to consider,â says Charles Adi, a Certified Financial Planner at the advisory firm Blueprint 360 in Houston. âI encourage my clients to take some time and evaluate the three critical retirement planning areas: income, expenses and insurance.â First, determine your monthly income and spending needs in retirement. âBe careful not to underestimate your discretionary budget for travel, shopping, eating out and spoiling the grandkids,â Adi says. âYou will be surprised how quickly small purchases add up.â Ask yourself this key question: Will there be areas you can cut back expenditures, say, by moving to a smaller home or town where the cost of living is cheaper? See: There is more to picking a place to retire than low taxes â avoid these 5 expensive mistakes Websites likeÂ Mint.comÂ andÂ YouNeedABudget.comÂ offer free software to track spending and set up budgets. If youâre offered an early retirement package, really scrutinize it.Â Buyouts are often complicated and not cookie-cutter. Most are negotiable to some extent, too. You have to truly understand what the deal is thatâs being offered, says Dennis Notchick, a Certified Financial Planner for Stratos Wealth Advisors in San Diego. That goes beyond how much money youâll receive, which is often related to your tenure with your employer. âIs it a lump sum? Is there anÂ annuityÂ option, lifetime income payments?â Notchick says. A lump-sum buyout can balloon your income for the year which can result in a significant tax bill. If you can take the payments in stages, that could lower your IRS bill. If you are married, youâll want to pay special attention to the payout rules. âSometimes a person will take a lifetime income payment, but if they die, their spouse gets nothing. Sometimes a survivorship benefit of fifty percent or two-thirds is an option,â says Notchick. To immunize yourself against future tax rate hikes due to federal deficit spending, Notchick says, you may want to use some of your early retirement money to open a tax-sheltered Roth IRA. Be sure to review any medical coverage, too. A typical offer includes one year of health coverage. Access to an employer health plan might be something you can negotiate for an extended period of coverage. When job-based plan coverage ends (and youâre not yet eligible for Medicare), you can usually continue enrollment for up to 18 months â sometimes longerÂ â under a federal law known asÂ COBRA, which stands for the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act. It requires firms with at least 20 employees to offer this option. Normally, you have up to 60 days to elect COBRA and another 45 days to pay the first premium (covering the period dating back to your coverage loss). But if youâve been laid off or furloughed due to the pandemic, aÂ recent federal rule gives you more time to decide about COBRA. The date to elect COBRA now begins March 1 (the end of the COVID-19 âoutbreak periodâ) and will end 60 days after whenever the government ultimately declares the COVID-19 emergency over. So, according to NPR, if you were laid off in April and the COVID-19 emergency ends Aug. 31, youâd have 60 days beginning Aug. 31 â the end of October â and then the regular 60-day COBRA election period after that. See: 5 things to know about health care in retirement So, people laid off because of the coronavirus outbreak have at least four months, maybe more, to decide whether they want to elect COBRA. The drawback: COBRA premiums are steep. Figure on something like $600 a month per person or more. âFinally,â Notchick says, âis long term care of concern? Are you currently covered by a long-term care policy at work? If so, can you keep it when you retire? And is it worth keeping?â Determine your retirement income sources.Â Carefully review your anticipated income (Social Security benefits, pensions, distributions from personal investments and savings) and expenses (weekly, monthly and yearly budgets). Many major mutual-fund companies have retirement calculators on their sites that can help you with this exercise. âFocus first on guaranteed sources, such as Social Security and pensions. Then calculate your monthly cash needs from investments,â Adi says. âIf you are fortunate to have a pension, evaluate your payout options and determine if your pension payment adjusts for inflation annually.â The Social Security Administration website can let you get anÂ estimate of your future Social Security benefitsÂ and a record of your lifetime earnings history. If youâre married, youâll need to determine when itâs best for each of you to start claiming Social Security. âDo you need to trigger both you and your spouseâs Social Security policies when you retire?â Notchick asks. âCan you take one or both later and let it increase?â The AARP website has a usefulÂ Social Security benefits calculator. Plan your withdrawals from savings and investments. A conservative annual drawdown of retirement savings may be to take 3% the first year, and to adjust for inflation after that. If youâve been fortunate enough to have saved $1 million, for example, plan to withdraw $30,000 in the first year and to increase that amount by the rate of inflation in the second year and beyond. Some financial advisers stick with the 4% rule for retirement withdrawals. âEvaluate your annual expenses and multiply this by 25,â Connell says. âThis will give you the amount of money you must have order to qualify for standard 4% withdrawal rate and not run out of money.â If youâre not taking an early retirement offer with health coverage and are thinking of retiring before 65, be sure to take health insurance into account. You wonât yet be eligible for Medicare, so health insurance will be a huge consideration. Also on MarketWatch: Where should I retire? If you have a spouse who is still working, you may be able to tap into health coverage via his or her employer. Otherwise, look into Affordable Care Act options throughÂ healthcare.govÂ or your stateâs marketplace. At 59, I currently shell out around $800 a month for a health insurance plan that has a high annual deductible: $7,500. Talk to a financial adviser.Â An expert can help you work through your early retirement puzzle. I recommend working with a fee-only financial adviser, rather than one who charges commissions. And look for one who is a fiduciary â which means this pro puts your interests first. Some databases to search for a certified financial planner: the nonprofit Certified Financial Planner Board of Standards, the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, the Financial Planning Association and Wealthramp.com. Kerry Hannon is the author ofÂ âNever Too Old to Get Rich: The Entrepreneurâs Guide to Starting a Business Mid-Life.â She has covered personal finance, retirement and careers for the New York Times, Forbes, Money, U.S. News & World Report and USA Today, among other publications. She is the author of a dozen books. Her website isÂ kerryhannon.com. Follow her on TwitterÂ @kerryhannon.
